subject: Re: [junit] JUnit 4
msgSnippet: ... Does this show you what I mean? public class AllTests { @Decorate(class=com.foo.WrapTestsInAdapterBeforeRunning.class) public static Test suite() throws
messageBody:
Kent Beck wrote:

> Jason,
>
> Convenient usage of JUnit 4 test with older runners is one of our
> goals. Can
> you give me a specific example where a decorator would make this possible?
> AFAIK, IDEs look for subclasses of TestCase or classes implementing a
> static
> suite() method to identify tests. A JUnit 4 test runner would also
> look for
> classes that reference the @Test annotation. The JUnit4TestAdapter is
> there
> to bridge the gap with older runners. It is a pain to have to copy and
> edit
> the suite() method, but I don't see how a decorator would solve the
> problem
> better.

Does this show you what I mean?

public class AllTests {

@Decorate(class=com.foo.WrapTestsInAdapterBeforeRunning.class)
public static Test suite() throws Exception {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite();
suite.addTestSuite(ConfigurationTest.class);
suite.addTest(FunctionalTests.suite());
suite.addTest(UnitAndDatabaseTests.suite());
return suite;
}
}

However, after giving this more thought I realized that we could do
something easier without using the decorator annotations. We use a
modified junix.util.DirectorySuiteBuilder to build the individual suites
referenced in the previous example. Within that class we could
determine that we are running with JUnit4 and wrap the class with the
adapter /as/ we add it to the suite instead of trying to decorate it
later. So, I guess my idea blows up in my face -- but at least it blew
up early in the cycle!

--
Jason Rogers
